Hypotheses # and name: CS.1 - Manufacturers Need Certified Local Suppliers
Hypotheses: Manufacturers (aerospace, medical devices, automotive) struggle to find certified local 3D printing facilities within their region, resulting in weeks of sourcing time and high shipping costs.
Early Adopter: Procurement Managers at mid-size manufacturers (100-1000 employees) who order 3D printed parts monthly and are frustrated with current 3-week sourcing cycles.

Hypotheses: 3D printing service bureaus and contract manufacturers have 30-40% idle machine capacity and struggle with expensive customer acquisition ($5-10K per client)
Early Adopter: Owners/operators of small-medium 3D printing facilities (5-20 machines) who are actively seeking new clients and willing to pay commission for qualified leads.

Hypotheses # and name: CS.3 - Labs & Authorities Need Digital Compliance System
Hypotheses: Certification labs and regulatory authorities spend 60%+ of their time on manual administrative tasks (paper-based requests, manual tracking) and lack centralized visibility into certifications across the industry.
Early Adopter: Quality managers at mid-size testing labs and forward-thinking compliance officers at regulatory bodies who are frustrated with manual processes and want better oversight tools.

Hypotheses: OEMs want to enable distributed 3D printing manufacturing to scale production but are blocked by concerns about quality control, IP protection, and lack of standardized processes.
Early Adopter: Engineering managers at industrial equipment OEMs who have explored distributed manufacturing but haven't implemented due to quality/IP concerns.

Hypotheses: Manufacturers have a functional job-to-be-done: source certified 3D printed parts for production/prototyping within 1-2 weeks maximum. Current process takes 3-4 weeks.
Early Adopter: Procurement managers with monthly part orders

Hypotheses: 3D printing facilities have a functional job: fill idle machine capacity (currently 30-40% idle) with qualified, paying clients to maximize revenue per machine
Early Adopter: Facility operators with <70% utilization

Hypotheses: Certification labs and regulatory authorities have a functional job: process certification requests and track compliance efficiently while minimizing administrative burden and maintaining oversight.
Early Adopter: Quality managers handling 50+ requests/month and compliance officers tracking 100+ facilities

Hypotheses: OEMs have a functional job: enable local/regional manufacturing of their parts through certified 3D printing facilities while maintaining quality control and IP protection.
Early Adopter: Engineering managers at OEMs with distributed customer base

Hypotheses: Manufacturers waste 3+ weeks and $75K+ annually in employee time searching for and vetting certified 3D printing facilities through manual Google searches, cold calls, and reference checks.
Early Adopter: Procurement teams without established supplier networks

Hypotheses: Manufacturers pay 40-60% more in shipping costs and experience 2-3 week longer lead times when using distant 3D printing suppliers instead of local options.
Early Adopter: Manufacturers ordering heavy/large 3D printed parts

Hypotheses: Manufacturers struggle to verify and prove that 3D printed parts meet regulatory requirements (ISO, FDA, FAA), creating audit risk and production delays.
Early Adopter: Manufacturers in highly regulated industries (aerospace, medical)

Hypotheses: 3D printing facilities lose $100K-$300K annually in potential revenue due to 30-40% idle machine capacity that could be filled with additional client work.
Early Adopter: Facilities with recent capex in new machines

Hypotheses: 3D printing facilities spend $5-10K per new client acquisition through trade shows, sales calls, and marketing, making small-value clients unprofitable.
Early Adopter: Facilities with limited marketing budget

Hypotheses: ertification labs spend 60% of staff time on manual administrative tasks (email requests, paper forms, manual scheduling) instead of actual testing work.
Early Adopter: Labs experiencing growth/backlog

Hypotheses: Regulatory authorities lack centralized systems to proactively track 3D printing certifications across their jurisdiction, forcing them to rely on reactive enforcement after problems occur.
Early Adopter: Compliance officers frustrated with manual tracking and blind spots

Hypotheses: OEMs struggle to maintain quality control and protect IP when using multiple distributed 3D printing facilities, leading them to avoid distributed manufacturing entirely.
Early Adopter: OEMs with quality control concerns blocking distributed production

Hypotheses: Manufacturers would gain significant value from finding certified local 3D printing facilities in minutes instead of weeks, reducing sourcing time by 90%+.
Early Adopter: Time-sensitive manufacturers with frequent orders

Hypotheses: anufacturers would gain 40-60% shipping cost reduction and 1-2 weeks faster delivery by using local 3D printing facilities instead of distant suppliers.
Early Adopter: Manufacturers with high shipping costs

Hypotheses: Manufacturers would gain peace of mind and audit readiness from having instant access to certification proof and compliance documentation for all 3D printed parts.
Early Adopter: Manufacturers in regulated industries facing audits

Hypotheses: 3D printing facilities would gain $100K-$300K additional annual revenue by filling their 30-40% idle capacity with qualified client work from the platform.
Early Adopter: Facilities with recent equipment investment

Hypotheses: 3D printing facilities would gain 50%+ reduction in customer acquisition costs (from $5-10K to <$3K via commission) by receiving qualified leads through the platform.
Early Adopter: Facilities struggling with sales/marketing

Hypotheses: Certification labs would gain 60% reduction in administrative time, allowing them to focus on actual testing work and increase throughput by 40%+
Early Adopter: Labs with backlogs and growth targets

Hypotheses: Regulatory authorities would gain real-time visibility into all certifications and compliance status across their jurisdiction, enabling proactive oversight instead of reactive enforcement.
Early Adopter: Forward-thinking compliance officers seeking better oversight tools

Hypotheses # and name: G.8 - Distributed Mfg with Quality Assurance
Hypotheses: OEMs would gain the ability to scale production through distributed 3D printing facilities while maintaining quality control and IP protection through standardized processes and monitoring.
Early Adopter: OEMs with regional customer base seeking faster delivery

Hypotheses: A searchable database of pre-vetted, certified 3D printing facilities (filterable by location, certification, capabilities) would enable manufacturers to find qualified suppliers in minutes instead of weeks.
Early Adopter: Procurement managers with urgent part needs

Hypotheses: An algorithm that prioritizes local/regional 3D printing facilities (within 100-500 miles) would reduce shipping costs by 40-60% and lead times by 1-2 weeks for manufacturers.
Early Adopter: Manufacturers ordering heavy/bulky parts

Hypotheses: Integrated certification tracking that provides instant proof of compliance (ISO, FDA, FAA certifications) would eliminate audit risk and save manufacturers weeks of documentation gathering.
Early Adopter: Manufacturers in heavily regulated industries

Hypotheses: A marketplace that brings pre-qualified client leads to 3D printing facilities would increase capacity utilization and reduce customer acquisition costs from $5-10K to <$3K (via 10-15% commission).
Early Adopter: Facilities with <70% utilization

Hypotheses: A verified certification badge system (integrated with labs) would help 3D printing facilities prove credentials to new clients and win more business.
Early Adopter: Facilities with certifications but struggling to prove them

Hypotheses: A digital certification workflow (online requests, automated scheduling, digital reporting) would reduce labs' administrative time by 60%, allowing them to focus on actual testing work.
Early Adopter: Labs experiencing growth/backlog

Hypotheses: A centralized compliance dashboard that aggregates all certification data would enable regulatory authorities to monitor industry compliance in real-time and identify non-compliant facilities proactively.
Early Adopter: Compliance officers seeking better visibility

Hypotheses: A platform that standardizes quality requirements and provides secure design file sharing would enable OEMs to scale distributed 3D printing manufacturing while maintaining quality control and IP protection.
Early Adopter: OEMs with distributed customer base

Hypotheses: 3D printing facilities will pay 10-15% commission on jobs received through the platform because it's cheaper than their current $5-10K customer acquisition cost.
Early Adopter: Facilities with high current CAC

Hypotheses: Manufacturers will pay $5K-$25K annually for premium features (priority matching, expedited certification, analytics) after experiencing value from freemium basic access.
Early Adopter: High-frequency manufacturers (monthly orders)

Hypotheses: Certification labs will pay $10K-$50K annually to be listed as "verified partners" on the platform because it brings them more business and streamlines their workflow.
Early Adopter: Labs seeking to modernize and grow

Hypotheses: OEMs will pay $50K-$150K annually for enterprise distributed manufacturing management dashboard because it enables them to scale production while maintaining quality control.
Early Adopter: OEMs with urgent distributed manufacturing needs

Hypotheses: Attending industry conferences (RAPID + TCT, Formnext, AMUG) will generate 50+ qualified leads per event from clients, facilities, and labs.
Early Adopter: Conference attendees actively seeking solutions

Hypotheses: Publishing whitepapers and case studies on LinkedIn about certified local 3D printing will generate 20-30 inbound leads per month from procurement managers and facility operators.
Early Adopter: Active LinkedIn users researching solutions

Hypotheses: A real-time, transparent communication platform (messaging, status updates, document sharing) would reduce project delays by 30-50% and is valued more than any other single feature across all customer segments.
Early Adopter: Companies experiencing communication delays causing project timeline impacts (10+ person teams with external partners)

Hypotheses: Demand forecasting and pipeline visibility tools would enable 2-4 week advance planning (vs. current 1 week reactive planning) and increase capacity utilization by 15-25% for both manufacturers and facilities.
Early Adopter: Facilities with variable demand and manufacturers with unpredictable sourcing needs

Hypotheses: Platform must integrate with existing IoT/AI quality systems (vision detection, sensors, ML models) via API to be attractive to advanced manufacturers. Integration capability is table stakes, not competitive advantage.
Early Adopter: Technology-forward manufacturers already investing in Industry 4.0

Hypotheses: Manufacturers scaling production gain significant value from adaptive planning tools, peer benchmarking data, and scaling playbooks that acknowledge non-linear growth challenges (vs. simple linear capacity calculators).
Early Adopter: Facilities and OEMs currently scaling production (2-5x growth target)

Hypotheses: A matching algorithm optimized for precision (technical fit, budget alignment, timeline compatibility, certification match) rather than recall is 3x more valuable than a large database with poor filtering. Showing fewer, better matches increases conversion by 40%+.
Early Adopter: Procurement managers and facility operators who waste time on unqualified leads

Hypotheses: A decision support tool for selecting the appropriate certification body (based on product type, target market, customer requirements, timeline, cost) could save manufacturers $50K+ in wasted certifications and 2-4 months per product launch.
Early Adopter: Manufacturers launching new products requiring certification in multiple markets

Hypotheses: Platform must address INTERNAL team collaboration (engineering, procurement, quality, supply chain) not just buyer-supplier communication. Multi-role workspaces with role-based permissions reduce internal communication delays by 40%.
Early Adopter: Mid-size companies (50-500 employees) with cross-functional teams involved in sourcing decisions

Hypotheses: Displaying transparent pricing (or price ranges) upfront and enabling budget-based filtering would reduce time wasted on budget misalignment by 40% and improve lead-to-quote conversion by 25%.
Early Adopter: Facilities and manufacturers frustrated with budget misalignment causing wasted sales cycles

Hypotheses: Labs need access to specialized instruments they don't own, and would use a secure platform that enables confidential test requests to other labs without revealing proprietary project details, reducing turnaround time from weeks to days.
Early Adopter: Lab managers/directors who need external instruments monthly and are frustrated with slow physical shipping processes

Hypotheses # and name: VP.16 - Cost/ROI Decision Support Tools for Labs
Hypotheses: Labs would pay for decision support tools that help justify AM equipment investments by comparing costs, capabilities, and ROI vs. traditional manufacturing methods, reducing investment decision time from months to weeks.
Early Adopter: Lab directors/administrators evaluating equipment investments ($1M+ decisions)

Hypotheses # and name: VP.17 - Feasibility Assessment & Project Planning Tools
Hypotheses: Labs would value tools that help assess project feasibility based on material parameters, available instruments, and historical success/failure data before committing resources, reducing failed projects by 30-40%.
Early Adopter: Lab researchers + managers with high project failure rates (30%+ failed/delayed projects)

Hypotheses # and name:
NH.1 - Post-COVID
  Stock Depletion Creates AM Opportunity
Hypotheses: The shift from stock-based to pre-order supply chains (post-COVID) creates market gap that AM can fill by enabling on-demand production vs 12-week pre-orders.
Early Adopter: Manufacturers and facilities dealing with post-COVID supply chain disruption

Hypotheses # and name:
NH.2 - Obsolescence
  is Primary AM Adoption Driver
Hypotheses: Parts obsolescence (no longer manufactured) drives AM adoption more than innovation/cost savings - AM becomes ONLY option, not just better option.
Early Adopter: Offshore operators, marine industry, industrial equipment manufacturers with aging assets

Hypotheses # and name:
NH.3 - Lead Time
  Emergency Accelerates Adoption
Hypotheses: High downtime costs force companies to try AM in emergencies (despite risk aversion), which opens door to comfort and eventual regular adoption.
Early Adopter: Offshore operators, facility managers with critical downtime cost exposure

Hypotheses # and name:
NH.4 - Geographic
  Isolation Amplifies Local Manufacturing Need
Hypotheses: Regions with limited freight options (weather delays, single carriers, remote locations) have significantly higher pain from distant suppliers and gain more value from local AM hubs.
Early Adopter: Newfoundland, remote mining sites, offshore platforms, northern communities, isolated industrial facilities

Hypotheses # and name: NH.5 - Predictive Maintenance + Digital Inventory Integration
Hypotheses: Pairing condition monitoring/predictive maintenance with digital inventory enables proactive AM part ordering before failure (vs reactive emergency ordering).
Early Adopter: Facilities with IoT sensor infrastructure and AI/ML predictive maintenance initiatives

Hypotheses # and name:
NH.6 - AM Adoption
  Evolution: Emergency ‚Üí Comfort ‚Üí Innovation
Hypotheses: AM adoption follows predictable 3-phase evolution: (1) emergency use only, (2) success builds comfort for regular use, (3) exploration of design innovation beyond replication.
Early Adopter: Companies in Phase 1 (emergency) who can be moved to Phase 2 (regular) with platform support

Hypotheses # and name:
NH.7 - Certification
  is Primary Gatekeeper for Regulated Industries
Hypotheses: Without classification approvals and facility qualification (e.g. Lloyd's Register), AM cannot penetrate oil & gas, offshore, aerospace, or medical - certification is table stakes, not differentiator.
Early Adopter: Certification labs, regulatory authorities, certified facilities pursuing new markets

Hypotheses # and name:
NH.8 - Feasibility +
  Cost Drive AM Acceptance (Interview 6 - John Lidstone)
Hypotheses: First consideration for AM adoption is part-specific feasibility (is AM actually cheaper than traditional?) - round parts use machining, complex/cast components better for AM. Quantity also matters.
Early Adopter: Engineers evaluating AM vs traditional for specific parts - need decision support tools

Hypotheses # and name:
NH.9 - Digital
  Inventory Reduces Lead Time from Months to Weeks
Hypotheses: Scanning and digitizing parts for certification-ready digital inventory can reduce lead time from months to weeks when combined with AM production capability.
Early Adopter: Companies starting to digitize product inventory and seeking certification integration

Hypotheses # and name:
NH.10 - OEM IP
  Release is Critical Blocker
Hypotheses: To produce parts via AM, OEM must relinquish IP, or IP must be proven void/expired/open. AI-based patent search could help identify open-source opportunities. Need OEM relationships.
Early Adopter: OEMs open to distributed manufacturing partnerships, facilities seeking IP-cleared part libraries

Hypotheses # and name:
NH.11 - CQFA as
  Quebec AM Ecosystem Gateway (Interview 7 - Fanny Charreteur)
Hypotheses: Regional AM hubs like CQFA (Carrefour qu√©b√©cois de la fabrication additive) provide ecosystem access, partnership opportunities, and funding expertise (Sr&ED) that can accelerate platform adoption.
Early Adopter: Regional AM ecosystem organizations, innovation hubs, government-backed manufacturing consortia

Hypotheses: Platform must provide automated risk categorization (critical vs non-critical) to help users identify parts safe for AM adoption. This is THE primary decision factor and should be MVP feature.
Early Adopter: Engineers and procurement managers evaluating AM feasibility who need decision support for risk assessment

Hypotheses: Platform must integrate post-processing services (coatings, surface finishing, heat treatment) as these are critical for energy sector and often blocking factor for AM adoption. Network of qualified service providers needed.
Early Adopter: Energy sector manufacturers requiring coatings/finishing, AM facilities seeking to offer complete solutions

Hypotheses: Platform should integrate reverse engineering services to scan obsolete parts and create certification-ready digital library. This transforms one-off emergency solutions into reusable assets
Early Adopter: Companies with aging equipment and obsolete parts, reverse engineering firms seeking platform integration

Hypotheses: Platform should provide API integration with predictive maintenance systems (IoT sensors, CMMS) to enable proactive part ordering before failure. This is ultimate vision combining predictive analytics with digital inventory.
Early Adopter: Facilities with IoT infrastructure and predictive maintenance programs, Industry 4.0 early adopters
